snippet.textDisplay:
Italy also has one of the most dated and under-prepared healthcare systems in the world when it comes to 1st world countries.

Nobody is saying it isnt serious. But using Italy as a prime example is a gross exaggeration when other countries with better healthcare in place have reported much lower numbers AND were much quicker to flatten the curve or new infections.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hello everybody from Italy.
Well, the situation is serious, but I personally think we are doing our best to control it. No country in the world can be ready enough to face an event like that.
We are responding in the best way we can, using our whole creativity to solve problems and crisis. Fortunately Italy show its very best exactly in these situations. It's hard to say when we could came out from this.
From now on, I'm sure we will follow the instructions given to us to live more normally as possible. Even if we can go out for a simple walk in this nice spring sun. We need to be patient and calm: #everythingwillbefine #andratuttobene
snippet.textOriginal:
Hello everybody from Italy. 
Well, the situation is serious, but I personally think we are doing our best to control it. No country in the world can be ready enough to face an event like that. 
We are responding in the best way we can, using our whole creativity to solve problems and crisis. Fortunately Italy show its very best exactly in these situations. It's hard to say when we could came out from this. 
From now on, I'm sure we will follow the instructions given to us to live more normally as possible. Even if we can go out for a simple walk in this nice spring sun. We need to be patient and calm: #everythingwillbefine #andratuttobene

snippet.textDisplay: yes, this, the virus itself will kill infants, older people, people with weak immune systems, people who overtake meds or have taken inoculations/vaccinations fairly recently or has a greater affect of harming that person... the stuff is no joke if you are 15-40 and dont really take these things because your immune system is strong, you will be fine and it will blow over in about two to three weeks tops, if you get this and about a week later, you start to think you are recovering but still feel bad, thats your body telling you to get up, do your most basic and common human needs an GO BACK TO SLEEP, next time you wake up... you will understand very quickly why you should not go out... week two, yeah that's the worst... problem is, after your body starts to adapt to the virus, it will eventually become less and less effective in your body even though you still carry it. you yourself will be fine but now you are a carrier who can affect other people, this will last about a month to two months in peoples bodies and there for, they very well dont even know they are spreading it... nasty stuff really

snippet.textDisplay: I can tell you right now that we'll probably end up worse then Italy at this rate. I go to work and I'm the only worker wearing gloves and a facemask. My management team tells me to take it off because it "scares the customers". I refuse. Elderly customers insult me for wearing it. I ignore them...but I'm the ONLY ONE. Hundreds of people cram into the building and nothing is being done to restrict how many people are coming in. Our face to face service counters are still open. Instead of trying to curb peoples panic our company put everything on sale which made it worse instead of better. It's a joke. I'm not even worried about getting sick...I'm worried about what happens if everything shuts down and I need something. I have a diabetic cat and another with heart disease. What if vets close down and I can't get the meds I need? I am poor so buying a months worth of supplies is impossible...my weekly budget for groceries is only $80. Getting sick is the least of my worries at this point.
snippet.textOriginal: I can tell you right now that we'll probably end up worse then Italy at this rate. I go to work and I'm the only worker wearing gloves and a facemask. My management team tells me to take it off because it "scares the customers". I refuse. Elderly customers insult me for wearing it. I ignore them...but I'm the ONLY ONE. Hundreds of people cram into the building and nothing is being done to restrict how many people are coming in. Our face to face service counters are still open. Instead of trying to curb peoples panic our company put everything on sale which made it worse instead of better. It's a joke. I'm not even worried about getting sick...I'm worried about what happens if everything shuts down and I need something. I have a diabetic cat and another with heart disease. What if vets close down and I can't get the meds I need? I am poor so buying a months worth of supplies is impossible...my weekly budget for groceries is only $80. Getting sick is the least of my worries at this point.

Hello everyone. A lot of you have been asking to subtitle the video in your own language to be able to send it around your countries. We have turned community subtitling on so now you can add your own subtitles to the video directly here.

To add subtitles in your language click the three dots next to the title and then click "Add translations".

Thank you everyone for spreading the message. Hope you're all safe.
A THING BY

snippet.textDisplay:
Bello il senso del video, bello tutto eh.

Ma:

- SE NON SEI STATO INFETTATO;
- SE NON SEI UN IPOTETICO CASO DI PAZIENTE INFETTO;
- SE NON SEI UNA PERSONA SANA CHE SI PRENDE COSTANTEMENTE CURA DI UNA PERSONA INFETTA

LE MASCHERINE NON SERVONO A NULLA, MANNAGGIA LA MISERIA. Avete rotto i maroni co ste minchia di mascherine.

Lo volete capire che una delle principali vie di infezione sono (anche) gli occhi? Vestire SOLO le mascherine NON SERVE A NULLA (eccezion fatta per i casi sopracitati), NON VI RENDERÀ IMMUNI DAL VIRUS.

L’utilizzo delle mascherine è, tra le altre cose, una tematica complessa. Esistono vari tipi di mascherine per i diversi usi. NON SONO TUTTE UGUALI e vanno indossate/maneggiate con cura, non “at canis cazzum” come fa il 99% della popolazione. Andate ad informarvi prima, vi prego.

Le mascherine lasciamole per tutti gli operatori sanitari, ricercatori, biologi, medici, infermieri e personale che ne hanno veramente bisogno.

- Un ricercatore biomedico stremato dalla continua ignoranza che dilaga.

snippet.textDisplay: People need some serious "perspective" in this matter, the population of Italy is 60,550,075 and the number of cases is at 25,000. THIS VIRUS IS AFFECTING 0.00057 OF THE ITALIAN POPULATION. Be proactive in your health care, however, one must understand panic is NOT proactive. Shutting down the world is only going to prolong this virus' impact NOT eliminate it. "The first two cases of the new Coronavirus (COVID-19) in Italy were recorded between the end of January and the beginning of February 2020. Since then, the number of cases in Italy increased steadily, reaching approximately 25 thousand as of March 16, 2020. The region most hit by the virus in the country was Lombardy, with 13.2 thousand cases." https://www.statista.com/statistics/1101680/coronavirus-cases-development-italy/
snippet.textOriginal: People need some serious "perspective" in this matter, the population of Italy is 60,550,075 and the number of cases is at 25,000. snippet.textDisplay:
Just in case people didn’t know, this is how far Hong Kong people have gone to try to contain COVID-19. And it has worked to an extent (134 cases for a city of 7mil people as of 13 March and a special administrative region of China):

- Working at home except for people like postmen, drivers, doctors, etc (for 7 weeks now);
- Schools closed for 7 weeks now;
- Courts closed for 6 weeks;
- Universal masking (generally 100% in my neighbourhood, for 7 weeks now)- and where masks are in shortage, businessmen buy their own machines to manufacture them. Also, people mobilised ourselves to ensure the marginalised (the elderly, the poor, migrants) have masks in stock;
- Washing or sanitising our hands frequently- many restaurants and buildings provide alcohol sanitisers to customers or residents- when there's shortage, universities teach people how to home-make online;
- Border control over and quarantines for people who have visited high-risk regions;
- Refraining from social gatherings (I myself have not attended one for 8 weeks).

This is not self-promotion. I just want to let you know that the measures in place in your country are probably FAR from adequate. Don’t wait for your government to tell you to act. Act now.

We have gone through SARS and know how much it hurts. It’s not just an illness. Particularly painful is the loss of medical staff. Because it meant people who were kind and brave enough to choose to continue to perform their duties sacrificed. We still remember that 17 years on.

snippet.textDisplay: Every major gathering, event, most schools, most activities, any sports all the way down to children's sports, all cancelled in the USA. People are panic buying out everything in stores to prepare for social isolating. Our restaurants are empty here. Gyms empty. Parks have a quarter of the normal amount of people in them. We're 5 days deep into people making memes about the panic buying of supplies like toilet paper. My entire town social media page is in full panic mode with people asking what to do and every other person on all my feeds urging people to stay home. Everyone I know who can work from home is being forced to do so from West to East coast. YET somehow we're not taking it seriously? Come on. And the thing about face masks is absurd, you don't need to buy face masks if you're keeping away from gatherings and keeping to small groups of friends and family like most of us already are. In fact, don't panic buy face masks because medical workers need them to be available. I'm sure someone will comment that someone somewhere posted some video of people still gathering in the USA. It's a country of 330 million people. 20 people in a bar doesn't mean we don't care. I live in the USA and I haven't had my life completely turned upsidedown so that everyone on the internet can tell me that we're taking it lightly.

snippet.textDisplay: Really, this is all about saving people who are really old or who already have serious medical issues.  It happened too fast in Italy and overwhelmed the Italian health care system, but America is grinding to a halt as we speak, and our health care system has a lot more resources to deal with it.  But this could still easily kill a few hundred thousand of our oldest, most fragile citizens, so let's all do our part to slow the spread and take care of our most vulnerable people.  Check in with any old people that you know by phone or email.  Make sure they have what they need to hunker down for a few weeks.  If they need supplies, go shopping for them so they don't have to go to the store and potentially expose themselves.  Otherwise, stay away from them so you don't inadvertently infect them.

snippet.textDisplay: We are very, very grateful that our governement in Quebec is taking this very, very seriously. We still only have about 37 cases, but today the governement closed the schools, universities, cinemas, pools, theaters, libraries, cancelled festivals, gatherings of more than 250 people, sports events, asked everybody to work from home as much as possible, retirement homes do not accept visitors anymore, people aged 70 years have to stay home. I hope we will be more successful in containing the virus. Italy, and everybody in the world, take this seriously. I wish you the best.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is a good message to the entire world


I'm in NYC, and I thought people were overreacting 2 weeks ago but I already stayed home most of the day because my job has me work from home now. I laughed it off as another flu which...technically it is, but not quite


Today, I know that I underestimated this damn virus and boy do I feel stupid thinking it was gonna be nothing. Even my friends were talking mad shit about me not wanting to visit them in Philadelphia today. While Philadelphia may not be as affected by NYC, I'm not taking the risk


Hell, someone in my apartment building on another floor went to the hospital yesterday for pneumonia, a symptom of this damn virus. Mad respect for the building staff for quickly cleaning up everything. But now my friends at least understand how close the danger is to me


So far my family up in Connecticut is unaffected and I hope it stays that way. As much as I want to go home and stick it out with my family, well for all I know I've accidentally contracted the virus during my shopping and it'd just be inappropriate to risk giving it to my family


While I'm certain I will not die if I somehow catch it because I'm young and healthy, I know that some poor bastard with a worse immune system might die if I catch it and spread it. So my ass is staying put until I need to step out for supplies
